articles.headline: A Day of Wild Market Swings and Global Anxiety
articles.snippet: At one point, major stock indexes were down more than 10 percent from their peak last month, but Thursday’s session ended with a wimper, not a bang.
articles.abstract: At one point, major stock indexes were down more than 10 percent from their peak last month, but Thursday’s session ended with a wimper, not a bang.
articles.lead_paragraph: What looked as if it would be one of the worst days since Wall Street began its midsummer swoon ended yesterday with a whimper, not a bang.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Louis Uchitelle

articles.headline: A Billion Dollars Later, New Orleans Still at Risk
articles.snippet: While parts of the city are now substantially safer from possible floodwaters, others have changed little.
articles.abstract: While parts of the city are now substantially safer from possible floodwaters, others have changed little.

articles.headline: With Markets Moving Wildly, Insight Suffers
articles.snippet: Why is the credit panic of 2007 being played out in slow motion? Information may arrive instantly, but insight takes longer.
articles.abstract: Why is the credit panic of 2007 being played out in slow motion? Information may arrive instantly, but insight takes longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-first-century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

articles.headline: For Giuliani, Ground Zero as Linchpin and Thorn
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani has raised the hackles of 9/11 rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani has raised the hackles of 9/11 rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigns around the country highlighting his stewardship of New York City after the Sept. 11 attacks, he is widely hailed for bringing order to a traumatized city. But he has also raised the hackles of rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.

articles.headline: At Treasury, the Secretary Waits It Out
articles.snippet: At Goldman Sachs, Henry M. Paulson, now the Treasury Secretary, was known for his aggressive deal-making. But as this month’s financial disorder has spread, Mr. Paulson has remained on the sidelines.

articles.headline: Big Changes and Big Loan for Lender
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial said it had tapped $11.5 billion in emergency financing from 40 of the world’s largest banks amid difficulties in selling its home loans.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial said it had tapped $11.5 billion in emergency financing from 40 of the world’s largest banks amid difficulties in selling its home loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shut out of the short-term debt market by an expanding credit crisis, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, turned yesterday to 40 of the biggest banks, borrowing $11.5 billion as it tried to shore up its cash.

articles.headline: Asia Seen as Better Able to Deflect Waves From U.S.
articles.snippet: The U.S. used to be able to pick up the slack when growth stalled in the rest of the world.  Now that dynamic has reversed, but many countries are still worried that the U.S. could drag them down as well.
articles.abstract: The U.S. used to be able to pick up the slack when growth stalled in the rest of the world.  Now that dynamic has reversed, but many countries are still worried that the U.S. could drag them down as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Aug. 16 — In the past, when economic growth has stalled in the rest of the world, the United States has usually been there to pick up the slack. Now that dynamic is reversed.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Padilla Is Guilty on All Charges in Terror Trial
articles.snippet: Jose Padilla, an American who was designated an “enemy combatant,” now faces life in prison.
articles.abstract: Jose Padilla, an American who was designated an “enemy combatant,” now faces life in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Aug. 16 — In a significant victory for the Bush administration, a federal jury found Jose Padilla guilty of terrorism conspiracy charges on Thursday after little more than a day of deliberation.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Scott Shane
